text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"I'm in my mid-30s, and have been working in content for around a decade. I started my career as a journalist, then transitioned over to content and loved everything about it. That said, with each passing year, I feel like the old person in the room.

Is content a young person's game? And (for the sake of discussion), for anyone looking to transition out of content marketing but still stay in marketing, what's another niche of marketing that fits a content skillset?"

• Bloody hell, is mid-thirties old now? 
• ‘Demand Gen’ marketers are in massive, er, demand at the moment. There’s generally a significant content function in those roles.

elements.text: Bloody hell, is mid-thirties old now?
‘Demand Gen’ marketers are in massive, er, demand at the moment. There’s generally a significant content function in those roles.

text:
Content doesn’t have an age limit imo (mid 40s, leading content & brand). I do feel like things like running social etc have a time limit, so it depends on how much of the “doing” you’re doing vs strategy and leadership etc. 

Regardless of age, in addition to what <@UUKNRAD4Z> said, I think product marketing (particularly the GTM side) is a good role many CMMs can transition to.

elements.text: Content doesn’t have an age limit imo (mid 40s, leading content & brand). I do feel like things like running social etc have a time limit, so it depends on how much of the “doing” you’re doing vs strategy and leadership etc.
Regardless of age, in addition to what
said, I think product marketing (particularly the GTM side) is a good role many CMMs can transition to.

text: This question could have been written by me just a bit ago. I'm 42, been writing online content for 13 years, and KNOW that I've been passed over for younger writers for content projects. I don't stress it, however. I've learned to understand my brand and what I do well and what I don't do well. (Research a new technology and offer clean copy with a smile? Yes. Write to vague brand guidelines that require me to use younger slang and what I've been told is a "pithy tone"? Nope. I'm guessing you have something you've nurtured in your brand that only you can offer (or at least someone with your experience), and the right clients will LOVE you for it. That said, if you're not willing to be as eager to research, embrace technology and trends, or accept input as you were when you were younger, it may be hard to make it. But this doesn't sound like the case, as all. (Hey, you're here!) I went from magazines to newspapers to branded content, and while I am often the oldest person in the room, my experiences are seen as super valuable by the right client. Please don't sell yourself short. And avoid clients that would make you think otherwise. If you want to transition out of content marketing because you don't enjoy it, fine. But don't feel "pushed" out.
